events.description: Boswellia sacra thrives in extreme heat. The trees require a specific balance: they cannot tolerate heavy monsoon rains, but they thrive on the high humidity and fog these monsoons bring to the mountains. Therefore, plantations are "hidden" on the northern slopes of the mountains and in the adjacent desert wadis. Desert dwellers discovered the fragrant drops of resin and discovered that, in addition to their incredible aroma, the resins also possessed antiseptic properties.
events.name: Discovery of incense

events.description: Proto-Sabaean communities coalesce around the Marib oasis in the highlands of modern Yemen. Seasonal monsoon floods from Wadi Dhana sustain barley, wheat, and date palm cultivation. The settlement controls a natural bottleneck on overland routes linking the frankincense-producing Dhofar coast to Mediterranean markets. Early earth dams channel floodwater into fields
events.name: abaean Kingdom at Marib

events.description: Almaqah, the moon god of the Sabaeans, presides over a pantheon that includes Athtar (the god of Venus), Shams (the sun goddess), and Dhat Hamyma (the goddess of war and fertility). Almaqah's symbols‚Äîa bull's head, bunches of grapes, lightning bolts, and a curved sickle weapon‚Äîare found on temples, steles, and incense burners throughout Yemen. The ruling dynasty considers itself his 'seed' (descendants). Priests perform rain-making rituals during droughts and perform ritual hunts (the 'game of Attar and Qurum') to bring rain. Temples serve the dual function of legal and political centers, used for swearing oaths, resolving disputes, and carving confessions into walls.
events.name: Cult of Almaqah ‚Äî Moon God and Sabaean Pantheon

events.description: Sabaeans develop a sophisticated terraced agriculture on Yemen's mountain escarpments. Farmers transport soil by donkey to fill platforms carved into the near-vertical slopes, creating stepped gardens irrigated by gravity cisterns and rainwater canals. Sorghum, wheat, barley, and grapes are grown on terraces at altitudes exceeding 2,000 meters. This highland agriculture complements the lowland dam irrigation in Marib, providing Saba with food security in two ecological zones.
events.name: Highland Terracing ‚Äî Mountain Agriculture of Saba

events.description: According to the Bible (1 Kings 10) and the Quran (Surah 27), the Queen of Sheba travels to Jerusalem with a great caravan carrying 120 talents of gold, spices, and precious stones to test King Solomon's wisdom. In Ethiopian tradition she is called Makeda, and their union produces Menelik I ‚Äî founder of the Solomonic dynasty that ruled Ethiopia until 1974.
events.name: Queen of Sheba Visits King Solomon

events.description: The domestication and selective breeding of Arabian dromedary camels transforms trade in Arabia. Wild dromedaries of the Arabian Peninsula are bred for endurance, water conservation, and load-bearing capacity‚Äîan adult camel can carry 240 kg (500 lb) over 30 miles (48 km) per day over terrain impassable to donkeys or oxen. The camel saddle evolves from a cushion to a rigid frame capable of carrying heavy loads. This technology makes the 2,000-kilometer overland route commercially viable for the first time, allowing the Sabeans to transport frankincense from Dhofar to Mediterranean markets in large quantities.
events.name: Camel Domestication in Arabia

events.description: The Sabaean Musnad script ‚Äî a 29-letter consonantal alphabet carved in angular, geometric forms optimized for stone ‚Äî becomes standardized for monumental inscriptions. Evolved from Proto-Sinaitic alongside Phoenician, it is a sibling to the scripts that will become Greek, Latin, and Hebrew. A parallel cursive variant called Zabur is used on wooden sticks for daily commerce and private records.
events.name: Sabaean Monumental Writing

events.description: The Temple of Awwam (Mahram Bilqis) is a representative temple complex throughout South Arabia. Dedicated to Almaqah as the "Lord of Awwam," it serves as the main oracular center of the Sabaean kingdom‚Äîpilgrims pray to the god through cleromancy (divination by marked arrows) and oneiromancy (divination by dreams after sleeping in the temple).
events.name: Temple of Awwam

events.description: Marib was the heart of the economy, technology and culture of the Sabaean kingdom. Marib becomes a monumental city with multi-story buildings, stone fortifications, and carved alabaster facades.
events.name: Marib - administrative capital of Saba

events.description: Sirwa was the first capital of the Sabaeans before the rise of Marib and later served as their "military capital." The city was heavily fortified and located on a strategic incense trade route. One of the most important temples to the god Almaqah is located here.
events.name: Sirwah - the first capital of the Sabeans

events.description: Sabaean rulers adopt the title 'mukarrib' (federator/unifier) rather than 'king', reflecting a confederation of tribes united under Saba's leadership. The mukarrib leads combined armies, adjudicates inter-tribal disputes, and serves as the earthly representative of the moon god Almaqah. The Mukarribi gather in Sirwa, the spiritual and political center of Saba
events.name: Mukarrib Confederation ‚Äî Sabaean Political System

events.description: Mukarrib Yatha'amar Watar I oversees the first major construction phase of the Great Marib Dam, transforming a simple earth barrier into a stone-faced structure. His name appears in Sabaean inscriptions at Sirwah, and ‚Äî crucially ‚Äî in Assyrian records as 'It'amra', making him the first Sabaean ruler independently confirmed by an external civilization.
events.name: Yatha'amar Watar I ‚Äî First Sabaean Ruler in Assyrian Records

events.description: The Great Ma'rib Dam is being built across Wadi Dana - a pyramidal earthen embankment with a stone lining, 580 m long, originally 4 m high, with sluices and spillways feeding a network of irrigation canals. It captures seasonal monsoon rains and creates the largest artificial oasis in ancient Arabia, irrigating 10,000 hectares of agricultural land. The dam will be built over centuries, rising to 14 meters in height, and making Saba the richest kingdom in Arabia.
events.name: Great Dam of Marib

events.description: Every year in February/March, all subjects of the Kingdom of Saba are required to make the pilgrimage to Marib. The 8-10-day festival begins at the Temple of Harwanum and proceeds in a procession to the Temple of Awwam along the sacred road. Pilgrims undergo mandatory purification: sexual abstinence, dietary restrictions, no weapons. On the seventh day, bulls are sacrificed to Almaqah‚Äîbulls are his sacred animals, symbolized by the ubiquitous motif of the bull's head and grapevine in Sabaean art. This is followed by communal meals on stone benches inside the temple. Bloodshed is prohibited during the pilgrimage.
events.name: Annual Pilgrimage to Almaqah ‚Äî Sabaean Sacred Festival

events.description: The Barran Temple (Throne of Bilqis) is built in the southern oasis of Marib, dedicated to Almaqah. Six monolithic stone columns rise to a height of over 12 meters, framing a sacred courtyard with a central well. Located near the Temple of Awwam, it is part of a pilgrimage route. Later, folklore associated it with the Queen of Sheba.
events.name: Barran Temple at Marib

events.description: Mukarrib Karib'il Watar launches military campaigns documented in the Temple of Almaqah in Sirwa. His most devastating campaign destroys the kingdom of Awsan: 16,000 killed, 40,000 captured, the palace of King Muratta destroyed, all temples and inscriptions destroyed, the entire Wadi Marha depopulated. Awsan disappears from history for six centuries. He later conquers Nashan, the Tihama coast, and Najran. He earns the nickname "Destroyer of Buildings" and imposes the cult of Almaqah in every conquered territory.
events.name: The Sabeans ravage Awsan

events.description: Mukarrib Yada'il Dharih I, son of Sumhu'ali, undertakes the most ambitious construction program in Sabaean history. He walls the entire sanctuary of the Temple of Awwam with its massive elliptical enclosure, builds the monumental walls of the Temple of Almaqah in Sirwa, and erects the sanctuary of Al-Masajid south of Marib. His inscription reads: 'Yada'il Dharih, son of Samah Ali, mukarrib of Saba, built the surrounding wall of the temple of Almaqah.'
events.name: Yada'il Dharih I ‚Äî Master Builder of Sabaean Temples

events.description: Karib'il Watar or his successor changes the royal title from 'mukarrib' (federator) to 'malik' (king), marking the transformation of Saba from a tribal confederation into a centralized monarchy. The professional royal army‚Äîthe khamis‚Äîis subordinate to the king, along with tribal units led by aristocratic chieftains (kayla). The king controls the frankincense trade, administers justice in the temples, and proclaims the divine sanction of Almaqah.
events.name: Birth of Sabaean Monarchy

events.description: Extracted from the organised mines of Jabal al-Mahdara north of Sirwa, the calcite alabaster is turned on machines, carved into sculptures, sculpted into bas-reliefs and cut into 3-centimetre sheets used as translucent window glass. Sabaean sculpture is distinguished by its ‚Äúcubist‚Äù forms, frontality and some schematicity. Typical features include massive shoulders, short legs, and a lack of fine detail on the body, while the faces are more elaborate.
events.name: Sabaean Alabaster Art

events.description: The Frankincense Route at its peak‚Äîa network of caravan routes over 2,000 km long, stretching from the frankincense groves of Dhofar and the myrrh-bearing highlands of Yemen north through Shabwa, Marib, Najran, Yathrib (Medina), and Dedan to Gaza and Petra on the Mediterranean. Saba controls taxation at the southern chokepoints, making frankincense and myrrh as valuable as gold. Every kingdom along the route levies tolls, and deviation from the route is punishable by death.
events.name: Incense Route at Peak ‚Äî Frankincense Trade Dominance

events.description: The structure of society and tribal law are documented in temple inscriptions. The population is organized into shaab (peoples/tribes), led by kayls (lords). Each clan (bayt) is obligated to the king and tribe. Marriage customs include formal negotiations regarding kalym, recorded in legal inscriptions. The jambiya‚Äîa curved dagger worn on the stomach‚Äîserves as a symbol of male honor and tribal identity, a tradition that continues to this day. Customs of hospitality are codified: guests receive food, shelter, and protection as sacred obligations.
events.name: Sabaean Tribal Law

events.description: Frankincense and myrrh permeate every level of Sabaean society. Resin is harvested by tapping Boswellia sacra trees in Dhofar and Commiphora myrrha in Yemen's highlands. Incense is burned daily in homes, temples, and public spaces. The Almaqah temples contain alabaster incense burners with animalistic motifs. Incense is offered for healing, protection during childbirth, military victories, and rain. Sabaean society revolves around the incense cycle: harvesting in the spring, the departure of caravans in the fall, and pilgrimage festivals tied to trade.
events.name: Frankincense Culture ‚Äî Sacred Aromatics of Saba

events.description: Official overseers, recruited on a rotating basis from Sabaean clans, manage the distribution of water from the Ma'rib Dam canal network. Each overseer controls their own sluice gates and canal junctions, determining which fields receive water and when. Disputes over water are resolved in temples and recorded in inscriptions. The system ensures a balanced distribution of water between the gardens of the northern and southern oases, and the rotation of overseers protects against monopolization of water by individual clans.
events.name: Sabaean Irrigation Bureaucracy

events.description: Those who violated the sacred law‚Äîentering the sanctuary impure, violating sexual prohibitions, or committing crimes against women or servants‚Äîwere required to publicly confess their misdeeds in stone. The inscriptions record divine punishment (usually an illness sent by Almaqah) and rituals of atonement: animal sacrifice, monetary payment, or the making of votive offerings. Women figure as both transgressors and victims in these texts.
events.name: Confessional Inscriptions in Sabaean Temples

events.description: The Ma'rib dam was raised from 4 meters to 7 meters, with a stone lining extended to the south. Five spillways direct water into a settling basin and a 1-kilometer-long distribution canal, feeding the orchards of the northern and southern oases. Irrigation provides two harvests of barley, wheat, dates, and grapes per year. Ma'rib's population grows to tens of thousands, making it the largest city in Arabia. Hydraulic engineers maintain precise slope calculations throughout the canal network‚Äîone of the most complex hydraulic systems of the ancient world.
events.name: Marib Dam Expansion

events.description: The Qataban kingdom, one of the six South Arabian kingdoms, is fighting for the frankincense trade route with Saba
events.name: The Katagan kingdom competes with Sheba

events.description: The Minean kingdom (Ma'in) in northwestern Yemen competes with Saba for control of the frankincense trade. The Mineans establish trading colonies as far away as Dedan (Al-Ula) in the Hejaz and the island of Delos in Greece. Saba's monopoly splinters into a multi-kingdom rivalry that will shape South Arabian politics for the next four centuries.
events.name: Minaean Kingdom Challenges Sabaean Monopoly

events.description: The Ptolemies in Egypt develop maritime trade along the Red Sea, bypassing the land-based Arabian caravans. Merchants learn to exploit the monsoon winds for direct sailings to India and East Africa, displacing the Sabaean middlemen from the most profitable segments of the spice trade. The Ptolemies found ports at Myos Hormos and Berenice. This undermines the economic basis of all the South Arabian kingdoms ‚Äì Saba, Ma'in, Qataban and Hadhramaut ‚Äì by redirecting centuries-old overland trade flows to cheaper and faster sea routes.
events.name: Ptolemaic trade in the Red Sea

events.description: Shabwah, the capital of Hadhramaut, acts as a key hub for raw frankincense entering the Sabaean-controlled trade network. All frankincense leaving the Dhofar region must pass through Shabwah's customs warehouses, where royal officials weigh, sort, and tax the resin before it is shipped northwest to Marib and the Mediterranean. Strabo records that a tithe of all frankincense passing through Shabwah is given to the god Sayyin. The city's 60 temples‚Äîone for each Hadhramite clan‚Äîmake it the most temple-dense settlement in South Arabia.
events.name: Shabwah ‚Äî Frankincense Gateway of Hadhramaut

events.description: The Great Dam of Marib suffers a catastrophic breach during the war between Raydan and Saba ‚Äî possibly the 'Flood of the 'Arim' referenced in the Quran (Surah 34:15-17). The breach devastates the northern oasis gardens and triggers emergency repairs. This is the first of six major breaches over seven centuries. Each subsequent repair becomes more difficult as hydraulic engineering knowledge deteriorates and political instability weakens the state's capacity for large-scale public works
events.name: First Breach of the Marib Dam

events.description: Ptolemy's maritime trade devastated the economy of southern Arabia. Kingdoms whose economies relied on overland frankincense caravans began to weaken. The Himyarites, who lived in the coastal region, staked their claim on control of the ports, broke away from Qataban, and established their capital in Zafar. The Himyarites created a new identity, proclaiming themselves rulers of Zu Raydan.
events.name: Secession of the Kingdom of Himyar

events.description: Taking advantage of the weakening of Saba after the Roman invasion, Himyar attacked Saba and captured key points of maritime trade on the southwest coast of South Arabia. The Himyar chieftains take the title 'King of Sheba and Dhu Raydan'. Without maritime trade and with its land trade fading, Saba is steadily weakening.
events.name: Himyarite Conquest ‚Äî End of the First Sabaean Kingdom

events.description: The Romans considered southern Arabia a fabulously rich land. Strabo wrote explicitly that Augustus wanted either to befriend the wealthy Arabs or to conquer them, gaining control of their frankincense and gold. In 26‚Äì25 BCE, the Roman prefect of Egypt, Aelius Gallus, undertook a campaign in Arabia Felix, on Augustus' orders. Roman legions reached the capital of Saba, Marib, and laid siege to it, but were forced to retreat after six days due to disease and thirst.
events.name: Siege of Marib by Romans

events.description: Roman prefect Aelius Gallus leads 10,000 legionaries from Egypt through the Hejaz toward Marib, aiming to seize control of the incense trade at its source. The Nabataean guide Syllaeus deliberately misleads the army through waterless desert. After six months of marching, disease, and attrition, the Romans reach Marib but fail to breach its fortifications. They withdraw after a two-week siege, losing most of their force to dysentery and dehydration on the return march. It is Rome's only military expedition into Arabia Felix ‚Äî and a complete disaster. Augustus never attempts it again
events.name: Roman Expedition of Aelius Gallus ‚Äî Siege of Marib

events.description: The Periplus of the Erythraean Sea, a Greek merchant's navigation guide, describes Saba's remaining trade network. The author notes that Muza (modern Mocha) serves as Saba's primary Red Sea port, exporting myrrh, alabaster, and locally-woven textiles. Eudaemon Arabia (Aden) ‚Äî 'once a full-fledged city' ‚Äî has been sacked and reduced to a village. Arabia Felix's internal trade still flows through Marib and Sana'a, but the overland frankincense caravans are a shadow of their former volume.
events.name: Periplus of the Erythraean Sea ‚Äî Greek View of Saba

events.description: The Sabaean kingdom reemerges as the "Middle Sabaean Kingdom," freed from Himyarite control. Significantly different from the previous kingdom, it functions with Sana'a as a second capital alongside Marib. The Sabaeans regain their territory, but now compete with Himyar, Hadramawt, and the remnants of Qataban in the fragmented South Arabian landscape.
events.name: Middle Sabaean Kingdom

events.description: The Ghumdan Palace is being built in Sana'a. According to the 10th-century historian al-Hamdani, it is a 20-story tower with four facades of multicolored stone: white, black, green, and red marble. Its top floor, the "Bilqis Hall," has a transparent alabaster ceiling through which the inhabitants can observe the sky. The palace serves as the royal residence for the late Sabaean and then Himyarite kings.
events.name: Ghumdan Palace in Sana'a

events.description: Sabaean architectural columns evolve from rectangular monoliths to rounded forms with decorated capitals, reflecting growing Hellenistic influence through trade with the Ptolemaic and Seleucid worlds. Multi-story tower buildings in Marib and Sana'a‚Äîwith stone foundations, mud walls, wooden beams, and alabaster window panes‚Äîcreated a distinctive Yemeni architectural tradition of tower houses, which continues to this day in the Old City of Sana'a.
events.name: Sabaean Tower Architecture

events.description: The Himyarite King Shammar Yuhar'ish permanently conquers Saba and assumes the title 'King of Saba and Dhu Raydan and Hadhramaut and Yamanat' ‚Äî unifying all of southwestern Arabia. Saba loses its royal status forever and reverts to an ordinary tribe limited to the citizens of Marib. The Sabaean language gradually gives way to a Himyaritic dialect. Almaqah's temples are eventually abandoned
events.name: Fall of Saba

events.description: Abu Karib Asad, the king of Himyar, led a large-scale expedition to northern Arabia, seeking to expand the borders of the empire to Syria. In Yathrib (Medina), the governor, his son, was killed. He vowed to destroy the city. While it lay under siege, local rabbis cured him of his illness and convinced him to abandon the city to a prophet from the Quraysh line. Abukarib himself accepts Jewish teaching and takes rabbis with him to Yemen.
events.name: The King of Himyar converts to Judaism

events.description: King Abu Karib brought back Jewish teachings from his northern campaign. Judaism granted Himyar the status of a "civilized people of the Book" and monotheism; and also provided the opportunity for an independent policy and a third way - Himyar was not bound by Christianity and the goals of Byzantium; nor was he bound by Zoroastrianism and the goals of Sassanid Persia
events.name: Judaism in Himyar

events.description: The Great Dam of Marib suffers its final catastrophic breach after six major failures over seven centuries. This time no one repairs it. The irrigation system collapses completely, the oasis dies, and an estimated 50,000 people migrate from Marib across the Arabian Peninsula ‚Äî the Azd tribe to Oman, Kindah to central Arabia, Ghassanids to Syria. The Arabic proverb 'separated like the hands of Saba' commemorates this diaspora.
events.name: Final Collapse of the Marib Dam
